Cow's milk is the milk of the domestic cow. It is a common food for humans, and is also used to produce dairy products such as cheese, butter, yogurt, ice cream, and kefir.

Cow's milk is a white liquid produced by the mammary glands of mammals. It is the primary source of nutrition for infant mammals (including humans who are breastfed) before they are able to digest other types of food.
Dairy products are food produced from the milk of mammals. They are primarily produced from mammals such as cattle, water buffaloes, goats, sheep, camels, and humans.

Cows are domesticated ungulates. A cow's udder is called a bag, and the milk from it is called milk.
Cattle are commonly raised as livestock for meat (beef or veal, see beef cattle), for milk (see dairy cattle), and for hides, which are used to make leather.

Milk is a white liquid produced by the mammary glands of mammals. It is the primary source of nutrition for infant mammals (including humans who are breastfed) before they are able to digest other types of food.

Cattle are ruminants, meaning their digestive system allows use of otherwise indigestible foods by regurgitating and rechewing them as "cud".

Cattle—colloquially cows—are the most common type of large domesticated ungulates. They are a prominent modern member of the subfamily Bovinae, are the most widespread species of the genus Bos, and are most commonly classified collectively as Bos taurus.
Cattle are domesticated ungulates.
